doctor_notes.content:
Patient presented with complaints of seasonal allergies. Symptoms include nasal congestion, sneezing, and itchy eyes persisting for 2 weeks. Patient reports taking OTC Zyrtec with partial relief.

Vital signs within normal range. Clear lung sounds, no wheezing or distress. No sinus tenderness observed.

Assessment: Seasonal allergic rhinitis

Plan:
1. Continue Zyrtec 10mg daily
2. Add Flonase nasal spray 1-2 sprays each nostril daily
3. Avoid known allergens, keep windows closed during high pollen times
4. Return if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 2 weeks
doctor_notes.summary: Follow-up for seasonal allergies. Prescribed Flonase in addition to existing Zyrtec regimen. Patient advised on allergen avoidance.

doctor_notes.content:
Patient presented for asthma check-up. Reports using rescue inhaler about 2-3 times per week, mostly after exercise. No nighttime symptoms. No ER visits or systemic steroids needed since last visit.

Lung examination reveals good air entry bilaterally, occasional end-expiratory wheeze after forced exhalation.

Spirometry results: FEV1 85% of predicted. No significant change from previous.

Assessment: Moderate persistent asthma, well controlled.

Plan:
1. Continue Albuterol inhaler as needed
2. Reviewed proper inhaler technique
3. Encouraged regular exercise with appropriate warm-up
4. Follow up in 6 months or sooner if symptoms worsen
doctor_notes.summary: Routine asthma check-up. Current regimen is effective with good control. No changes to medications needed.

doctor_notes.content:
Initial patient consultation. Patient reports no significant health issues aside from asthma (diagnosed age 12) and seasonal allergies. Current medications include Albuterol inhaler (as needed) and OTC Zyrtec for allergies.

Physical examination within normal limits. Vitals: BP 120/78, HR 72, RR 14, Temp 98.6Â°F, SpO2 98%.

Family history significant for diabetes (father) and hypertension (both parents).

Assessment: Healthy 38-year-old female with well-controlled asthma and seasonal allergies.

Plan:
1. Routine bloodwork including CBC, CMP, lipid panel, HbA1c
2. Continue current medications
3. Recommended annual flu vaccine
4. Discussed importance of regular exercise and balanced diet given family history
5. Follow up in one year for routine physical or sooner if needed
doctor_notes.summary: Initial patient consultation. Patient is generally healthy with controlled asthma and seasonal allergies. Routine bloodwork ordered. Discussed preventive measures given family history of diabetes and hypertension.
